articles.headline: F.B.I., Laying Out Evidence, Closes Anthrax Case
articles.snippet: The bureau released a report adding new details to its case that the attacks were carried out by Bruce E. Ivins, an Army biodefense expert who killed himself in 2008.
articles.abstract: The bureau released a report adding new details to its case that the attacks were carried out by Bruce E. Ivins, an Army biodefense expert who killed himself in 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than eight years after anthrax-laced letters killed five people and terrorized the country, the F.B.I. on Friday closed its investigation, adding eerie new details to its case that the 2001 attacks were carried out by Bruce E. Ivins, an Army biodefense expert who killed himself in 2008.

articles.headline: A Card Fee Still Hides in the Luggage
articles.snippet: The Credit Card Act is reducing some fees, but the one on foreign transactions, an industry profit center, was not touched.
articles.abstract: The Credit Card Act is reducing some fees, but the one on foreign transactions, an industry profit center, was not touched.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starting Monday, your credit card company will have to follow a long list of new rules.

articles.headline: For Texas Pilot, Rage Simmered With Few Hints
articles.snippet: The amateur pilot who crashed his plane into an I.R.S. building was described as a companionable family man.
articles.abstract: The amateur pilot who crashed his plane into an I.R.S. building was described as a companionable family man.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.  He arrived, as so many do, from California, graying and open-faced, working in the computing industry, quietly nursing strong feelings about the government and moonlighting with a rock band.

articles.headline: Bloomberg Shifts $5 Billion Out of Friend’s Firm
articles.snippet: The mayor is moving his fortune from Quadrangle Group 10 months after a scandal with the state pension fund.
articles.abstract: The mayor is moving his fortune from Quadrangle Group 10 months after a scandal with the state pension fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York has decided to remove his fortune from a private equity firm founded by his longtime friend, 10 months after that firm became embroiled in a scandal involving the state pension fund.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: F.C.C. Opens an Inquiry for a Game Show on Fox
articles.snippet: The F.C.C. is questioning whether some contestants of “Our Little Genius” were fed quiz answers in advance.
articles.abstract: The F.C.C. is questioning whether some contestants of “Our Little Genius” were fed quiz answers in advance.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The Federal Communications Commission is looking into whether the producers of the planned Fox game show “Our Little Genius” gave potential contestants the answers to some questions before taping episodes of the program last year.

articles.headline: Steelworkers Say Reactors Will Create Overseas Jobs
articles.snippet: The Obama administration says building a nuclear plant in Georgia would create jobs, but steelworkers said the parts would come from foreign manufacturers.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration says building a nuclear plant in Georgia would create jobs, but steelworkers said the parts would come from foreign manufacturers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United Steelworkers union has complained that a government-backed plan to build two nuclear reactors in Georgia will create jobs overseas that should go to American workers.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Report Faults 2 Authors of Bush Terror Memos
articles.snippet: A Justice Department report found that Bush administration lawyers used flawed reasoning on brutal interrogation tactics but were not guilty of professional misconduct.
articles.abstract: A Justice Department report found that Bush administration lawyers used flawed reasoning on brutal interrogation tactics but were not guilty of professional misconduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After five years of often bitter internal debate, the Justice Department concluded in a report released Friday that the lawyers who gave legal justification to the Bush administration’s brutal interrogation tactics for terrorism suspects used flawed legal reasoning but were not guilty of professional misconduct.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Rewards Cardholders Face a Higher Price for Perks
articles.snippet: Banks are focusing on a new constituency: the solvent. Banks are trying to get these people to pay higher fees for the promise of perks once subsidized by weaker borrowers.
articles.abstract: Banks are focusing on a new constituency: the solvent. Banks are trying to get these people to pay higher fees for the promise of perks once subsidized by weaker borrowers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rewards cardholders take note: the price of perks is about to go up.

articles.headline: An Accidental Leader Stirs Hopes in Nigeria
articles.snippet: That Acting President Goodluck Jonathan is eliciting such unusual hopes only a week into his tenure is testimony to the scale of the country’s neglected needs.
articles.abstract: That Acting President Goodluck Jonathan is eliciting such unusual hopes only a week into his tenure is testimony to the scale of the country’s neglected needs.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria  The circumstances of Acting President Goodluck Jonathan’s accession to power are so odd that even he looks bewildered as he takes a self-effacing bow in this boiling, fractious nation.

articles.headline: Marines Do Heavy Lifting as Afghan Army Lags in Battle
articles.snippet: The day when the Afghan Army will be able to perform complex operations independently, rather than merely assist American missions, remains far off.
articles.abstract: The day when the Afghan Army will be able to perform complex operations independently, rather than merely assist American missions, remains far off.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARJA, Afghanistan  As American Marines and Afghan soldiers have fought their way into this Taliban stronghold, the performance of the Afghan troops has tested a core premise of the American military effort here: in the not-too-distant future, the security of this country can be turned over to indigenous forces created at the cost of American money and blood.

articles.headline: Alexander M. Haig Jr. Dies at 85; Was Forceful Aide to 2 Presidents
articles.snippet: Mr. Haig was secretary of state under President Reagan and was the White House chief of staff as President Richard M. Nixon’s administration crumbled.
articles.abstract: Mr. Haig was secretary of state under President Reagan and was the White House chief of staff as President Richard M. Nixon’s administration crumbled.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alexander M. Haig Jr., the four-star general who served as a confrontational secretary of state under President Ronald Reagan and a commanding White House chief of staff as the Nixon administration crumbled, died Saturday at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, according to a hospital spokesman. He was 85.

articles.headline: For Professor, Fury Just Beneath the Surface
articles.snippet: Over the years, Amy Bishop, arrested last week in the shooting of six faculty members, had shown signs that a slight could set off a disproportionate reaction.
articles.abstract: Over the years, Amy Bishop, arrested last week in the shooting of six faculty members, had shown signs that a slight could set off a disproportionate reaction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long after Amy Bishop was identified as the professor who had been arrested in the shooting of six faculty members at the University of Alabama in Huntsville on Feb. 12, the campus police received a series of reports even stranger than the shooting itself.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan, Stephanie Saul and Katie Zezima

articles.headline: Xerox’s New Chief Tries to Redefine Its Culture
articles.snippet: Ursula Burns, the new C.E.O. of Xerox, wants its 130,000 employees to take more initiative and to become more fearless and frank with one another.
articles.abstract: Ursula Burns, the new C.E.O. of Xerox, wants its 130,000 employees to take more initiative and to become more fearless and frank with one another.
articles.lead_paragraph: Orlando, Fla.

articles.headline: Will Airlines and Passengers Call a Truce?
articles.snippet: Once passengers shell out hundreds of dollars for a ticket, the sales pitches begin: Checking a bag? Need a pillow? How about some trail mix?
articles.abstract: Once passengers shell out hundreds of dollars for a ticket, the sales pitches begin: Checking a bag? Need a pillow? How about some trail mix?
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN weather forecasters predicted severe winter storms across the country in the last few weeks, airlines sent their customers a steady stream of e-mail and text messages, giving them a chance to change their itineraries ahead of the bad weather.

articles.headline: Millions of Unemployed Face Years Without Jobs
articles.snippet: The social safety net was built for short-term gaps between jobs, but work may be scarce for years, even as the American economy shows signs of a rebound.
articles.abstract: The social safety net was built for short-term gaps between jobs, but work may be scarce for years, even as the American economy shows signs of a rebound.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENA PARK, Calif.  Even as the American economy shows tentative signs of a rebound, the human toll of the recession continues to mount, with millions of Americans remaining out of work, out of savings and nearing the end of their unemployment benefits.

articles.headline: For Chip Makers, the Next Battle Is in Smartphones
articles.snippet: Intel and its rivals are in a race to dominate a growing market for small mobile devices with chips that are inexpensive and use little power.
articles.abstract: Intel and its rivals are in a race to dominate a growing market for small mobile devices with chips that are inexpensive and use little power.
articles.lead_paragraph: The semiconductor industry has long been a game for titans.

articles.headline: Mea Culpa, at Arm’s Length
articles.snippet: Tiger Woods’s public apologia was the latest installment in his love/hate relationship with the media. But even then he managed to enforce Tiger Rules.
articles.abstract: Tiger Woods’s public apologia was the latest installment in his love/hate relationship with the media. But even then he managed to enforce Tiger Rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long before his public image became as badly dented as the Cadillac Escalade he was driving on Thanksgiving weekend, Tiger Woods wondered aloud about the appetite of the media.

articles.headline: Hacking Inquiry Puts China’s Elite in New Light
articles.snippet: Investigators looking into Web attacks on Google traced the intrusions to Jiaotong University and Lanxiang Vocational School, elite Chinese schools with strong American ties.
articles.abstract: Investigators looking into Web attacks on Google traced the intrusions to Jiaotong University and Lanxiang Vocational School, elite Chinese schools with strong American ties.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  With its sterling reputation and its scientific bent, Shanghai Jiaotong University has the feel of an Ivy League institution.

articles.headline: A Bus System Reopens Rifts in South Africa
articles.snippet: The system promises to ease the hardship of millions who live in townships far from cities, but opponents are pushing back.
articles.abstract: The system promises to ease the hardship of millions who live in townships far from cities, but opponents are pushing back.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOWETO, South Africa  Since the days of apartheid, when blacks were required to live in distant townships like this, Susan Hanong, a 67-year-old maid, has commuted to the wealthy northern suburbs of Johannesburg, one of the spectral figures trudging through darkened streets on long trips to wash white people’s clothes and mind their children.

articles.headline: Networks Wary of Apple’s Push to Cut Show Prices
articles.snippet: Apple wants to ignite TV show sales, especially as it prepares to introduce the iPad. But its proposals to lower prices are being met with skepticism from networks.
articles.abstract: Apple wants to ignite TV show sales, especially as it prepares to introduce the iPad. But its proposals to lower prices are being met with skepticism from networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: If Apple cut the price of each TV episode in half  to 99 cents, from $1.99  would sales on iTunes increase enough to offset the price drop?

articles.headline: Selling a Celebrity Look
articles.snippet: Web sites have made it easier for readers to shop for celebrities’ looks, letting them click on pictures to identify and buy the clothes they see famous people wearing.
articles.abstract: Web sites have made it easier for readers to shop for celebrities’ looks, letting them click on pictures to identify and buy the clothes they see famous people wearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The paparazzi tracked down Angelina Jolie and four of her children in Venice last week, snapping photos of them eating ice cream. Her fans analyzed the photos, looking for the presence of Brad Pitt, at her new blond highlights and for clues to what she was wearing.

articles.headline: Toyota Cited $100 Million Savings After Limiting Recall
articles.snippet: An internal memo claimed that the company saved millions by negotiating with U.S. regulators on a limited recall of floor mats.
articles.abstract: An internal memo claimed that the company saved millions by negotiating with U.S. regulators on a limited recall of floor mats.
articles.lead_paragraph: Toyota estimated that it saved $100 million by negotiating with regulators for a limited recall of 2007 Toyota Camry and Lexus ES models for sudden acceleration, the same problem that has since prompted it to recall millions of cars, documents turned over to a Congressional committee showed Sunday.

articles.headline: Judge Accepts S.E.C.’s Deal With Bank of America
articles.snippet: But in his ruling, the judge delivered harsh words for the S.E.C., saying that the settlement was “half-baked justice at best.”
articles.abstract: But in his ruling, the judge delivered harsh words for the S.E.C., saying that the settlement was “half-baked justice at best.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In a ruling that freed Bank of America from some legal problems, a federal judge wrote on Monday that he had reluctantly approved a $150 million settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
